message_1:
What is the bond dissociation energy (in kilojoules per mole) required to break the carbon-oxygen bond in carbon monoxide (CO) using the following equation?

CO(g) → C(g) + O(g)

Given the enthalpies of formation for CO(g), C(g), and O(g) are -110.5 kJ/mol, 716.7 kJ/mol, and 249.2 kJ/mol, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the bond dissociation energy, we can use the enthalpies of formation for the reactants and products in the equation:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f (products) - Σ ΔH_f (reactants)

In this case, the reaction is:

CO(g) → C(g) + O(g)

The enthalpies of formation for CO(g), C(g), and O(g) are -110.5 kJ/mol, 716.7 kJ/mol, and 249.2 kJ/mol, respectively.

ΔH_reaction = [(716.7 kJ/mol) + (249.2 kJ/mol)] - [(-110.5 kJ/mol)]

ΔH_reaction = (965.9 kJ/mol) + (110.5 kJ/mol)

ΔH_reaction = 1076.4 kJ/mol

Therefore, the bond dissociation energy required to break the carbon-oxygen bond in carbon monoxide (CO) is 1076.4 kJ/mol.
